title: Now that any Bible, Quran, etc., version can be accessed electronically, are computers, laptops, smartphones, tablets, etc., “holy”? - Quora

response.answer_text: My question if you think they’re not holy, would be ‘why do you think that just because it’s actually written on paper, it’s holy’? Oh I get it, the ink & paper must be blessed before it’s written on, NOT! The written word is the issue here, however it’s written, God blesses it because He doesn’t care! Think about the POW’s in Vietnam, they obviously didn’t have an ‘AUTHORIZED King James Bible there but they had a Bible, written from their memories, on whatever they got their hands on but it was still their only Bible!

As for the Bible, I would agree with Matheus Costa’s response, that it is the contents, the concepts, the ideas, the message of the holy book that are holy; ‘set aside for a purpose’, not the books, scrolls, parchments, animal skins, or computer chips that they are written on. I am not a lawyer, so couldn’t say as to the legality of an elected official swearing on a DVD containing a PDF of the Bible, or some such; I think that is more traditional than anything else. In an age of fast printing, and easily accessible copies of any book, the ‘holiness’ of a specific Bible is probably a concept that is no longer valid. Such a thing does not necessarily make it profane, or common, or without value, it just emphasizes how extraordinary its contents are.
